title: Building Age Estimation: A New Multi-Modal Benchmark Dataset and Community Challenge
author: Nikolaos Dionelis (European Space Agency), Nicolas Longepé (European Space Agency), Alessandra Feliciotti (MindEarth), Mattia Marconcini (MindEarth), Devis Peressutti (Sinergise/Planet), Nika Oman Kadunc (Sinergise/Planet), JaeWan Park (TelePIX), Hagai Raja Sinulingga (TelePIX), Steve Andreas Immanuel (TelePIX), Ba Tran (Axelspace Corporation), Caroline Arnold (Helmholtz Institute Hereon)
background: Estimating the construction year of buildings using multi-modal datasets to aid urban planning and sustainability efforts.
contribution: This paper introduces the Map your City Dataset (MyCD) to solve the problem of building age estimation, achieving competitive model performance even with data from previously unseen cities.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods generally used single-modal data (e.g., only street-view or satellite images) and struggled with generalizing to unseen environments.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by utilizing a multi-modal dataset combining street-view images, high-resolution satellite images, and multispectral data, significantly enhancing generalization performance.

key_innovation: The integration of diverse data modalities allows for improved accuracy in predicting the construction year of buildings, showcasing the importance of multi-view learning.
real_world_impact: The findings could have substantial implications for urban development and sustainability strategies by accurately estimating building energy efficiencies based on age. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The paper does not detail specific limitations but suggests the potential challenge of missing data modalities during inference.

new_terms.multi-modal data: **Multi-modal data** refers to information that is captured through different types of modalities, such as images from various perspectives (street and top view), enhancing the range of context available for analysis.

open_sourcing: The baseline model code and dataset are available at http://github.com/AI4EO/MapYourCity.
